<ce:figure id="FIG1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Perspective view of [Cd(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] molecule, showing 50% probability ellipsoids for the nonhydrogen atoms and the numbering scheme of the atoms in the molecule. Intramolecular hydrogen bonds are shown as thin lines.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Perspective view of [Cd(L1)2Br2] molecule, showing 50% probability ellipsoids for the nonhydrogen atoms and the numbering scheme of the atoms in the molecule. Intramolecular hydrogen bonds are shown as thin lines.

</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  View of the [Cd(L2)2I2] complex showing the numbering scheme adopted for the atoms.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="FIG3">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Perspective view of the asymmetric unit of [Hg(L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> showing the atom numbering scheme and the coordination geometry about the cadmium atom. Symmetry code is as given in <ce:cross-ref refid="TBL3">Table 3</ce:cross-ref>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  Perspective view of the asymmetric unit of [Hg(L2)I2] n  showing the atom numbering scheme and the coordination geometry about the cadmium atom. Symmetry code is as given in Table 3.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Reaction of 2-[1-(pyrrol-2-yl)methylidene]hidrazine carbothioamide (L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>) and 2-[1-(pyrrol-2-yl)ethylidene]hidrazine carbothioamide (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) with zinc(II) cadmium(II) and mercury(II) halides afforded complexes with formulae [M(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] [M, X=Zn, Cl (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>); Cd, Cl (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>); Hg, Cl (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>); Hg, Br (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>); Hg, I (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>)], [M(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] [M, X=Zn, Br (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>); Zn, I (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>); Cd, Br (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>); Cd, I (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>)], [M(L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] [M, X=Cd, Cl (<ce:bold>13</ce:bold>); Hg, Cl (<ce:bold>16</ce:bold>); Hg, Br (<ce:bold>17</ce:bold>); Hg, I (<ce:bold>18</ce:bold>)] and [M(L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] [M, X=Zn, Cl (<ce:bold>10</ce:bold>); Zn, Br (<ce:bold>11</ce:bold>); Zn, I (<ce:bold>12</ce:bold>); Cd, Br (<ce:bold>14</ce:bold>); Cd, I (<ce:bold>15</ce:bold>)]. Crystals of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>18</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>15</ce:bold>·CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN were studied by X-ray diffractometry, and all the new compounds were characterized by elemental analysis, mass spectrometry, IR and <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H and <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR spectroscopy and, when pertinent and allowed by the solubility of the compounds, <ce:sup loc="pre">113</ce:sup>Cd or <ce:sup loc="pre">199</ce:sup>Hg NMR spectroscopy. In these complexes, the metal atoms are tetra-coordinate and the ligands are neutral and S-monodentate.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Reaction of 2-[1-(pyrrol-2-yl)methylidene]hidrazine carbothioamide (L1) and 2-[1-(pyrrol-2-yl)ethylidene]hidrazine carbothioamide (L 2) with zinc(II) cadmium(II) and mercury(II) halides afforded complexes with formulae [M(L1)X2] [M, X=Zn, Cl (1); Cd, Cl (4); Hg, Cl (7); Hg, Br (8); Hg, I (9)], [M(L1)2X2] [M, X=Zn, Br (2); Zn, I (3); Cd, Br (5); Cd, I (6)], [M(L2)X2] [M, X=Cd, Cl (13); Hg, Cl (16); Hg, Br (17); Hg, I (18)] and [M(L2)2X2] [M, X=Zn, Cl (10); Zn, Br (11); Zn, I (12); Cd, Br (14); Cd, I (15)]. Crystals of 5, 18 and 15⋅CH3CN were studied by X-ray diffractometry, and all the new compounds were characterized by elemental analysis, mass spectrometry, IR and 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy and, when pertinent and allowed by the solubility of the compounds, 113Cd or 199Hg NMR spectroscopy. In these complexes, the metal atoms are tetra-coordinate and the ligands are neutral and S-monodentate.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Complexes between metals and thiosemicarbazone ligands exhibit a broad spectrum of biological properties, including antibacterial, antimalarial, antiviral and antineoplastic activities. . Chemically, heterocyclic thiosemicarbazones are of interest because of their great versatility as ligands, which derives from the presence of several potential donor atoms, their flexibility, and their ability to coordinate in either neutral or deprotonated forms.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Complexes between metals and thiosemicarbazone ligands exhibit a broad spectrum of biological properties, including antibacterial, antimalarial, antiviral and antineoplastic activities. . Chemically, heterocyclic thiosemicarbazones are of interest because of their great versatility as ligands, which derives from the presence of several potential donor atoms, their flexibility, and their ability to coordinate in either neutral or deprotonated forms.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In continuance of our work on the coordination chemistry of heterocyclic thiosemicarbazones, we describe here the synthesis and structural characterization of complexes between Group 12 metal halides and two thiosemicarbazones with pyrrole rings: 2-formylpyrrole thiosemicarbazone (L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>) and 2-acetylpyrrole thiosemicarbazone (L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>). In the complexes synthesized, both ligands are neutral and S-monodentate, as in some other thiosemicarbazone complexes of these metal cations .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In continuance of our work on the coordination chemistry of heterocyclic thiosemicarbazones, we describe here the synthesis and structural characterization of complexes between Group 12 metal halides and two thiosemicarbazones with pyrrole rings: 2-formylpyrrole thiosemicarbazone (L1) and 2-acetylpyrrole thiosemicarbazone (L2). In the complexes synthesized, both ligands are neutral and S-monodentate, as in some other thiosemicarbazone complexes of these metal cations .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>General</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All reagents were supplied by Aldrich, Ventron or Merck and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N, S) were performed on Carlo Erba EA-1108 elemental analyser. Melting points were determined in a Büchi apparatus. IR spectra were recorded in KBr discs (4000–400 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) or polyethylene-sandwiched Nujol mulls (500–100 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H and <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR spectra in DMSO-<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> were recorded on Bruker AMX-300 and WM-300 spectrometers, respectively, with Me<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Si as the internal reference. <ce:sup loc="pre">113</ce:sup>Cd NMR spectra in DMF referred to D<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, and <ce:sup loc="pre">199</ce:sup>Hg NMR spectra in DMSO-<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, were recorded on a Bruker AMX-500 apparatus and referred to 0.1 M Cd(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and HgMe<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, respectively. Mass spectra (FAB, 3-nitrobenzyl alcohol, Xe, 8 kV) were obtained on a Kratos MS-50 apparatus equipped with a DS-90 data acquisition unit.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General

All reagents were supplied by Aldrich, Ventron or Merck and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N, S) were performed on Carlo Erba EA-1108 elemental analyser. Melting points were determined in a Büchi apparatus. IR spectra were recorded in KBr discs (4000-400 cm-1) or polyethylene-sandwiched Nujol mulls (500-100 cm-1). 1H and 13C NMR spectra in DMSO-d 6 were recorded on Bruker AMX-300 and WM-300 spectrometers, respectively, with Me4Si as the internal reference. 113Cd NMR spectra in DMF referred to D2O, and 199Hg NMR spectra in DMSO-d 6, were recorded on a Bruker AMX-500 apparatus and referred to 0.1 M Cd(ClO4)2 and HgMe2, respectively. Mass spectra (FAB, 3-nitrobenzyl alcohol, Xe, 8 kV) were obtained on a Kratos MS-50 apparatus equipped with a DS-90 data acquisition unit.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of the complexes</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Complexes of formulas [M(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] [M, X=Zn, Cl (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>); Cd, Cl (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>); Hg, Cl (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>); Hg, Br (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>); Hg, I (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>)], [M(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] [M, X=Zn, Br (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>); Zn, I (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>); Cd, Br (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>); Cd, I (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>)], [M(L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] [M, X=Cd, Cl (<ce:bold>13</ce:bold>); Hg, Cl (<ce:bold>16</ce:bold>); Hg, Br (<ce:bold>17</ce:bold>); Hg, I (<ce:bold>18</ce:bold>)] and [M(L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] [M, X=Zn, Cl (<ce:bold>10</ce:bold>); Zn, Br (<ce:bold>11</ce:bold>); Zn, I (<ce:bold>12</ce:bold>); Cd, Br (<ce:bold>14</ce:bold>); Cd, I (<ce:bold>15</ce:bold>)] were synthesized by reacting L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> or L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with the corresponding metal salts in 1:1 mole ratio in 25 ml if ethanol. Prolonged stirring at room temperature afforded suspensions or solutions from which, after storage at low temperature or addition of a small quantity of water, filtration separated solids that were then dried in vacuo or over calcium chloride. In the case of [Cd(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), and [Hg(L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>18</ce:bold>), single crystals suitable for X-ray diffractometry were obtained by evaporation of the solvent from the filteres reaction mixture at room temperature. [Cd(L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN (<ce:bold>15</ce:bold>·CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN) was cristallized from methyl cyanide.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the complexes

Complexes of formulas [M(L1)X2] [M, X=Zn, Cl (1); Cd, Cl (4); Hg, Cl (7); Hg, Br (8); Hg, I (9)], [M(L1)2X2] [M, X=Zn, Br (2); Zn, I (3); Cd, Br (5); Cd, I (6)], [M(L2)X2] [M, X=Cd, Cl (13); Hg, Cl (16); Hg, Br (17); Hg, I (18)] and [M(L2)2X2] [M, X=Zn, Cl (10); Zn, Br (11); Zn, I (12); Cd, Br (14); Cd, I (15)] were synthesized by reacting L1 or L2 with the corresponding metal salts in 1:1 mole ratio in 25 ml if ethanol. Prolonged stirring at room temperature afforded suspensions or solutions from which, after storage at low temperature or addition of a small quantity of water, filtration separated solids that were then dried in vacuo or over calcium chloride. In the case of [Cd(L1)2Br2] (5), and [Hg(L2)I2] (18), single crystals suitable for X-ray diffractometry were obtained by evaporation of the solvent from the filteres reaction mixture at room temperature. [Cd(L2)2I2]⋅CH3CN (15⋅CH3CN) was cristallized from methyl cyanide.

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Crystals of 5, 15⋅CH3CN and 18 suitable for X-ray diffracton were mounted on glass fibers and transferred to an Enraf-Nonius CAD4 diffractometer for data collection using Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å). Crystal data and details of data collection and refinement are given in  . The data were corrected for Lp effects and for the observed linear decay of reference reflections. An empirical absorption correction (DIFABS)  was applied for all compounds. The structures were solved by direct methods and subsequent difference Fourier techniques , and were refined on F 2 . Neutral atom scattering factors and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from the International Tables for X-ray Crystallography . Geometrical calculations were performed and illustrations produced with shelxl-97 , zortep  and platon-99  packages.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Reaction of the pyrrole thiosemicarbazones L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with Group 12 metal halides in ethanolic media afforded, generally in good yield, the complexes listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL2"></ce:float-anchor>. The analytical data indicate metal:ligand mole ratios of 1:1 for the mercury complexes, the cadmium chloride complexes and [Zn(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], and 1:2 stoicheiometry for the other compounds. All the compounds were stable in air, moderately soluble in polar solvents other than water and insoluble in apolar solvents, and had melting points in the range 128–249°C. Only in a minority of cases did the FAB mass spectrum show a signal corresponding to the molecular ion, but in most cases an appropriate fragmentation sequence could be inferred: [M(L)X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>→[M(L)X]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>→[M(L)]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>→[L]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> for the 1:1 complexes, [M(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>X]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>→[M(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>→[M(L)]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>→[L]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> for the 1:2 complexes. Similar fragmentation sequences have been reported for other compounds of this type .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Reaction of the pyrrole thiosemicarbazones L1 and L2 with Group 12 metal halides in ethanolic media afforded, generally in good yield, the complexes listed in  . The analytical data indicate metal:ligand mole ratios of 1:1 for the mercury complexes, the cadmium chloride complexes and [Zn(L1)Cl2], and 1:2 stoicheiometry for the other compounds. All the compounds were stable in air, moderately soluble in polar solvents other than water and insoluble in apolar solvents, and had melting points in the range 128-249°C. Only in a minority of cases did the FAB mass spectrum show a signal corresponding to the molecular ion, but in most cases an appropriate fragmentation sequence could be inferred: [M(L)X2]+→[M(L)X]+→[M(L)]+→[L]+ for the 1:1 complexes, [M(L)2X]+→[M(L)2]+→[M(L)]+→[L]+ for the 1:2 complexes. Similar fragmentation sequences have been reported for other compounds of this type .

elements.clean_text:
Description of crystal structures

The structures of [Cd(L1)2Br2] (5), [Cd(L2)2I2]⋅CH3CN (15) and [Hg(L2)I2] (18) are shown in    , and   list their main bond lengths and angles. In all three, the thiosemicarbazone ligands are neutral and S-monodentate, with C(6)-S distances greater than 1.69 Å and C(6)-N(3) distances greater than 1.30 Å , and have the same conformations as in crystals of the free ligands .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>15</ce:bold> the cadmium atom is coordinated to the two halogen atoms and the S atoms of the two ligand molecules in a slightly distorted tetrahedral configuration. Greatest angular distortion from ideal tetrahedral geometry is shown in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> by Br(1)–Cd–Br(2) [101.62(3)°], and in <ce:bold>15</ce:bold> by S(2)–Cd–I(1) [98.80(5)°] and S(1)–Cd–I(1) [116.50(4)°]. The Cd–S and Cd–halogen distances () are similar to those found in other complexes with thiol or thiocarbonyl sulphur atoms , although the Cd–S bonds are shorter than in complexes with N,S-bidentate  or N,N,S-tridentate  thiosemicarbazone ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In 5 and 15 the cadmium atom is coordinated to the two halogen atoms and the S atoms of the two ligand molecules in a slightly distorted tetrahedral configuration. Greatest angular distortion from ideal tetrahedral geometry is shown in 5 by Br(1)-Cd-Br(2) [101.62(3)°], and in 15 by S(2)-Cd-I(1) [98.80(5)°] and S(1)-Cd-I(1) [116.50(4)°]. The Cd-S and Cd-halogen distances () are similar to those found in other complexes with thiol or thiocarbonyl sulphur atoms , although the Cd-S bonds are shorter than in complexes with N,S-bidentate  or N,N,S-tridentate  thiosemicarbazone ligands.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In <ce:bold>18</ce:bold>, also, the metal atom has coordination number four, being bound to the ligand sulphur atom and to three iodine atoms, two of which form bridges to neighbouring mercury atoms. These iodine bridges give rise to a linear polymeric structure along <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis, in which the ligand molecules of successive units lie on opposite sides of, and roughly parallel to, the central –I–Hg–I–Hg–I– backbone (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG4"></ce:float-anchor>). The coordination polyhedron is a highly distorted tetrahedron with S(1)–Hg–I(1)=127.93(6)° and I(2)<ce:sup loc="post">#</ce:sup>–Hg–I(2)=93.83(3)°. The Hg–S distance, 2.456(2) Å, and two of the Hg–I distances, 2.668(1) and 2.744(1) Å, are within the expected ranges for compounds of this type  (although Hg–S is shorter than in complexes with N,N,S-tridentate heterocyclic thiosemicarbazones , but the third Hg–I distance, 3.218(1) Å, is much longer, which accentuates the distortion of the coordination polyhedron and makes the iodine bridges very asymmetric. The distance between Hg atoms, 4.537(1) Å, is greater than the sum of the van der Waals radii, ruling out the possibility of a metal–metal bond.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In 18, also, the metal atom has coordination number four, being bound to the ligand sulphur atom and to three iodine atoms, two of which form bridges to neighbouring mercury atoms. These iodine bridges give rise to a linear polymeric structure along c axis, in which the ligand molecules of successive units lie on opposite sides of, and roughly parallel to, the central -I-Hg-I-Hg-I- backbone ( ). The coordination polyhedron is a highly distorted tetrahedron with S(1)-Hg-I(1)=127.93(6)° and I(2)#-Hg-I(2)=93.83(3)°. The Hg-S distance, 2.456(2) Å, and two of the Hg-I distances, 2.668(1) and 2.744(1) Å, are within the expected ranges for compounds of this type  (although Hg-S is shorter than in complexes with N,N,S-tridentate heterocyclic thiosemicarbazones , but the third Hg-I distance, 3.218(1) Å, is much longer, which accentuates the distortion of the coordination polyhedron and makes the iodine bridges very asymmetric. The distance between Hg atoms, 4.537(1) Å, is greater than the sum of the van der Waals radii, ruling out the possibility of a metal-metal bond.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The crystals of all three compounds feature numerous intra- and inter-moleccular hydrogen bonds (
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL4"></ce:float-anchor>). Most are between halogens and hydrogen-bearing nitrogens, but <ce:bold>15</ce:bold>·CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN has two N–H⋯N bonds, and both <ce:bold>15</ce:bold>·CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> have N–H⋯S bonds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The crystals of all three compounds feature numerous intra- and inter-moleccular hydrogen bonds ( ). Most are between halogens and hydrogen-bearing nitrogens, but 15⋅CH3CN has two N-H⋯N bonds, and both 15⋅CH3CN and 5 have N-H⋯S bonds.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Infrared spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL5"></ce:float-anchor> list the main IR bands of L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
 and of the new complexes. None of these compounds have any bands between 2000 and 2500 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, suggesting that the ligands are not in thiol form either before or after coordination, at least in the solid state. Coordination only significantly affects the <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(CS)+<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(CN) band, which (in all the complexes except <ce:bold>13</ce:bold>) shifts to slightly higher energies, and the <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(CS) band, which shifts to lower energies. These findings are coherent with the ligands having undergone no deprotonation and with their coordinating solely through the S atom, as was found in the X-ray study for <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>15</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>18</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Infrared spectra

   list the main IR bands of L1 and L2  and of the new complexes. None of these compounds have any bands between 2000 and 2500 cm-1, suggesting that the ligands are not in thiol form either before or after coordination, at least in the solid state. Coordination only significantly affects the ν(CS)+ν(CN) band, which (in all the complexes except 13) shifts to slightly higher energies, and the ν(CS) band, which shifts to lower energies. These findings are coherent with the ligands having undergone no deprotonation and with their coordinating solely through the S atom, as was found in the X-ray study for 5, 15 and 18.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>NMR spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="SCH1"></ce:float-anchor> shows the numbering used for assignment of <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H and <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR signals (
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL6"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL7"></ce:float-anchor>). The presence of all the ligand proton signals in the <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra of the complexes confirms non-deprotonation, and in most of these spectra the presence of two N(4)–H signals shows a magnetic non-eqivalence attributable to rotation about the C(6)–N(4) bond being impeded by partial double-bond character acquired upon S-coordination , and by hydrogen bonding. S-coordination also deshields most of the N(3) and N(4) protons, most markedly in the mercury complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
NMR spectra

   shows the numbering used for assignment of 1H and 13C NMR signals (  ). The presence of all the ligand proton signals in the 1H NMR spectra of the complexes confirms non-deprotonation, and in most of these spectra the presence of two N(4)-H signals shows a magnetic non-eqivalence attributable to rotation about the C(6)-N(4) bond being impeded by partial double-bond character acquired upon S-coordination , and by hydrogen bonding. S-coordination also deshields most of the N(3) and N(4) protons, most markedly in the mercury complexes.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">As expected if only the S atom coordinates, the <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR signals that are most affected by coordination are those of C(5), which all shift downfield, and C(6), which mostly shift upfield. In general, the pyrrole ring carbons are essentially unaffected, confirming that the heterocycle is not involved in coordination.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As expected if only the S atom coordinates, the 13C NMR signals that are most affected by coordination are those of C(5), which all shift downfield, and C(6), which mostly shift upfield. In general, the pyrrole ring carbons are essentially unaffected, confirming that the heterocycle is not involved in coordination.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL8"></ce:float-anchor> list the <ce:sup loc="pre">113</ce:sup>Cd and <ce:sup loc="pre">199</ce:sup>Hg NMR signals of the Cd and Hg complexes that are soluble enough to allow these spectra to be recorded. The <ce:sup loc="pre">113</ce:sup>Cd  and <ce:sup loc="pre">199</ce:sup>Hg  chemical shifts are within the expected ranges for these atoms in tetrahedral environments. In particular, the signals of the bromo and iodo Cd complexes lie upfield of those of penta-coordinated Cd in complexes with N,N,S-tridentate thiosemicarbazones , although the signal of the chloro Cd complex lies at lower field. Among both the Cd and Hg complexes, the chemical shifts exhibit the order Cl>Br>I, in keeping with the relative electronegativities of the halogens .</ce:para>

Prolonged stirring at room temperature afforded suspensions or solutions from which, after storage at low temperature or addition of a small quantity of water, filtration separated solids that were then dried in vacuo or over calcium chloride. In the case of [Cd(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), and [Hg(L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>18</ce:bold>), single crystals suitable for X-ray diffractometry were obtained by evaporation of the solvent from the filteres reaction mixture at room temperature. [Cd(L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN (<ce:bold>15</ce:bold>·CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN) was cristallized from methyl cyanide.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the complexes

Complexes of formulas [M(L1)X2] [M, X=Zn, Cl (1); Cd, Cl (4); Hg, Cl (7); Hg, Br (8); Hg, I (9)], [M(L1)2X2] [M, X=Zn, Br (2); Zn, I (3); Cd, Br (5); Cd, I (6)], [M(L2)X2] [M, X=Cd, Cl (13); Hg, Cl (16); Hg, Br (17); Hg, I (18)] and [M(L2)2X2] [M, X=Zn, Cl (10); Zn, Br (11); Zn, I (12); Cd, Br (14); Cd, I (15)] were synthesized by reacting L1 or L2 with the corresponding metal salts in 1:1 mole ratio in 25 ml if ethanol. Prolonged stirring at room temperature afforded suspensions or solutions from which, after storage at low temperature or addition of a small quantity of water, filtration separated solids that were then dried in vacuo or over calcium chloride. In the case of [Cd(L1)2Br2] (5), and [Hg(L2)I2] (18), single crystals suitable for X-ray diffractometry were obtained by evaporation of the solvent from the filteres reaction mixture at room temperature. [Cd(L2)2I2]⋅CH3CN (15⋅CH3CN) was cristallized from methyl cyanide.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Reaction of the pyrrole thiosemicarbazones L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with Group 12 metal halides in ethanolic media afforded, generally in good yield, the complexes listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL2"></ce:float-anchor>. The analytical data indicate metal:ligand mole ratios of 1:1 for the mercury complexes, the cadmium chloride complexes and [Zn(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], and 1:2 stoicheiometry for the other compounds. All the compounds were stable in air, moderately soluble in polar solvents other than water and insoluble in apolar solvents, and had melting points in the range 128–249°C. Only in a minority of cases did the FAB mass spectrum show a signal corresponding to the molecular ion, but in most cases an appropriate fragmentation sequence could be inferred: [M(L)X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>→[M(L)X]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>→[M(L)]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>→[L]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> for the 1:1 complexes, [M(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>X]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>→[M(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>→[M(L)]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>→[L]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> for the 1:2 complexes. Similar fragmentation sequences have been reported for other compounds of this type .</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Reaction of the pyrrole thiosemicarbazones L1 and L2 with Group 12 metal halides in ethanolic media afforded, generally in good yield, the complexes listed in  . The analytical data indicate metal:ligand mole ratios of 1:1 for the mercury complexes, the cadmium chloride complexes and [Zn(L1)Cl2], and 1:2 stoicheiometry for the other compounds. All the compounds were stable in air, moderately soluble in polar solvents other than water and insoluble in apolar solvents, and had melting points in the range 128-249°C. Only in a minority of cases did the FAB mass spectrum show a signal corresponding to the molecular ion, but in most cases an appropriate fragmentation sequence could be inferred: [M(L)X2]+→[M(L)X]+→[M(L)]+→[L]+ for the 1:1 complexes, [M(L)2X]+→[M(L)2]+→[M(L)]+→[L]+ for the 1:2 complexes. Similar fragmentation sequences have been reported for other compounds of this type .
